title: 109_hr5716
content: The Act may be cited as the "Iraq Transition Act of 2006". It includes findings and declarations of policy. The "Iraq Transition Act of 2006" includes findings that highlight significant progress in establishing a democratic government in Iraq, including the approval of Iraq's Constitution in a 2005 referendum and the election of a diverse parliament. The Iraq Transition Act of 2006 acknowledges the election of President Jalal Talabani and Prime Minister Nouri Kamal al-Maliki to form Iraq's first democratically-elected government. The US has spent 67% of $20.9 billion from the Iraq Relief and Reconstruction Fund on reconstruction efforts. Approximately 265,000 Iraqi Security Forces have been trained to take over security operations. Despite a democratically-elected government, civilian functions remain under US and Coalition military control. Congress declares policies in support of Iraq's transition. Congress declares policies in support of Iraq's transition to civilian control through a national commission empowered to oversee the process. A national commission was established at the close of World War II to oversee the transition of the Philippines to civilian control. Congress now aims to establish a similar commission to transition Iraq from US military to Iraqi civilian control in an orderly manner, with the expectation that the military will collaborate with the commission. The purpose of establishing a commission is to transition Iraq from US military to Iraqi civilian control in an orderly manner. The Act aims to establish a national commission to transfer power from US military forces to the newly-elected Government of Iraq, empowering Iraqi leaders and reducing reliance on US military forces. The commission will facilitate dialogue, report findings, and provide guidance for the transition of governmental responsibility. The Act establishes a national commission to transfer power to the newly-elected Iraqi government officials, ensuring proper use of US reconstruction assistance for Iraq. A commission called the "Commission on Iraqi Transition" is established by the Act to oversee the transfer of power to the newly-elected Iraqi government officials. The Commission on Iraqi Transition is composed of 21 members appointed by the President, Speaker of the House, minority leader of the House, and majority leader. The Commission on Iraqi Transition consists of 21 members appointed by various leaders. Seven members are appointed by the Senate leaders, with specific party allocations. Members must be appointed within 60 days and should be US citizens with relevant experience. Meetings must be held within 30 days of all appointments. The Commission on Iraqi Transition, comprised of 21 members appointed by various leaders, must hold its first meeting after all appointments are made. A quorum of at least 11 members, with bipartisan representation, is required for conducting business. Vacancies do not affect the Commission's powers and are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Chairperson is elected by the Commission members. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission is tasked with studying and reporting on the transfer of power for Iraqi Government operations from US military forces to the newly-elected Government of Iraq, focusing on key ministries and departments as established by the Iraqi Constitution and laws. The Commission is responsible for overseeing the transfer of power from US military forces to the newly-elected Government of Iraq, focusing on key ministries and departments. It aims to promote government-wide management goals such as accountability, effective management, efficiency, ethical conduct, and merit-based recruitment for the Iraqi Government. The Commission is responsible for overseeing the transfer of power to the newly-elected Government of Iraq, focusing on key ministries and departments. It aims to promote accountability, effective management, efficiency, ethical conduct, and merit-based recruitment for the Iraqi Government. SEC. 7. POWERS OF COMMISSION. The Commission, or its subcommittee or member, has the power to conduct hearings, issue subpoenas, and compel witnesses to testify and produce relevant documents for investigations under this Act. The Commission has the authority to issue subpoenas for witnesses to testify and produce documents. They can also enter into contracts to fulfill their duties. The Commission can obtain information directly from federal agencies for the purposes of the Act. Federal agencies can provide administrative support to the Commission as authorized by law. The Commission under the Act can receive administrative support services from the General Services Administration and other federal departments and agencies. They are also allowed to accept gifts, use postal services, and obtain services or property donations. SEC. 8. STAFF OF COMMISSION. The Chairperson of the Commission can appoint staff and set their compensation without following certain regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. The Commission can appoint staff and set their compensation without following regulations. Federal Government employees can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Consultants can be hired at rates not exceeding those of a level IV position under the Executive Schedule. SEC. 9. COMPENSATION AND TRAVEL EXPENSES. Members of the Commission may be compensated at a daily rate not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule. Federal employees serving on the Commission cannot receive additional pay. Travel expenses, including per diem, are provided for members while away from their homes or regular places of business. Members of the Commission may receive compensation at a daily rate not exceeding the annual rate of basic pay for a position at level IV of the Executive Schedule. They are also entitled to travel expenses, including per diem, while away from their homes or regular places of business. In addition, they may receive subsistence in the same manner as intermittent Government employees under section 5703(b) of title 5, United States Code. SEC. 10. Security clearances for Commission members and staff are to be provided expeditiously by Federal agencies or departments, following existing procedures and requirements. Access to classified information under this Act requires appropriate security clearances. SEC. 11. Commission reports, Congressional response, and termination. The Commission is required to submit an initial report within 90 days of its first meeting to the President and Congress, assessing progress in transferring authority to the newly elected Iraqi Government. Interim reports can also be submitted with agreed-upon findings, conclusions, and recommendations. A final report will be submitted when the majority of Commission members determine that governing authority has been transferred. The Commission will submit reports to Congress on the transfer of governing authority to the Iraqi Government. Congress can hold hearings and enact legislation based on the Commission's findings and recommendations. The Commission will terminate its activities once authority has been fully transferred. The Commission and its authorities will terminate within 90 days of submitting the final report. During this period, the Commission can conclude its activities, testify before Congress, and disseminate the final report. Authorization of appropriations is granted for necessary funds to carry out the Act, with amounts remaining available without time limit until spent.
